creator: draxus@dragonsrealm.com
text:
Using the default configure settings for a compiled from source version of 
Apache httpd 2.0.49 on Redhat Linux 6.2, & 9 Platforms

When accessing the URL to a user directory that doesn't have a public html 
directory or any other directory or file that the user doesn't have permissions 
to get to Apache returns a standard "403 Forbidden" Page that also includes the 
error "Additionally, a 403 Forbidden error was encountered while trying to use 
an ErrorDocument to handle the request."

This happens with the default 403 Forbidden Page.

With a custom ErrorDocument 403 is specified in the httpd.conf -

This Works:
ErrorDocument 403 "No Access"

These Don't Work:
ErrorDocument 403 /error403page.html
ErrorDocument 403 http://www.someothersite.com/error403.html

creator: beecher@columbia.edu
text:
We saw this bug when some file servers were offline for maintenance.  When accessing a symlink that 
points to a not-mounted filesystem Apache 2.0.53 gives the 403 Forbidden error instead of 404 File Not 
Found.  The error log contains "Symbolic link not allowed".  The error reporting script could not be 
invoked because "a 403 Forbidden error was encountered while trying to use..."  This is a serious problem 
for us because we use the error reporting script to inform users that system maintenance is underway.

Bug 1: Apache 2 gives 403 Forbidden instead of 404 File Not Found when symlink points to not-mounted 
filesystem
Bug 2: error logs says "Symbolic link not allowed" instead of "no such file"
Bug 3: error reporting script can't be invoked due to 403 Forbidden error

creator: draxus@dragonsrealm.com
text: This bug seems to have been resolved in the 2.20 version release of Apache httpd.
